Response: NA; we didn't have any changes

Cedars-Sinai has prioritized risk stratification efforts in order to tailor specific interventions to best meet the needs of our patients. We have also implemented care coordination efforts across the continuum of care, including pre-operative outreach for scheduled procedures, inpatient care coordination with close focus on transitions of care, and telephonic follow-up when a patient is at home or in a post-acute facility. Discharge and self-care education, management of comorbid conditions, and appropriate referrals to supportive care medicine have also all been enhanced. Telehealth developments are in process as we consider how to best implement at Cedars-Sinai. Cedars-Sinai is continuing to evaluate screening tools and methods for engaging community partners for social determinants of health.

In data analysis and feedback, we've partnered with a third-party vendor to allow us to closely monitor performance data for our selected episodes. We also hold regular meetings (both working group and executive review) to discuss the data and plan improvement cycles.
No challenges to meeting the CEHRT use requirements.
NA; we are a Non-Convener Participant

A challenge experienced was initial resistance to signing the agreements for providers with low case volume in the particular episode. Many providers had concerns their billing would be impacted by signing the agreement even though we are a non-convener participant. After they heard additional information regarding the program and Cedars-Sinai's goals for participation, providers were then interested in signing.

All program documentation is housed via network folder and the Cloud, including all CMS documentation, data analyses, internal decision-points and timelines. We have a project plan that outlines key dates for the program and guides decision-making. Multiple executives and project managers are involved, providing continuity in the event an individual departs the organization.
